<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We would like to assert that we actually read / wrote all the bytes that we</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// expected to for this record, but unfortunately we can&#39;t do this.  Some</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// producers such as MASM over-allocate for certain types of records and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// commit the extraneous data, so when reading we can&#39;t be sure every byte</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// will have been read.  And when writing we over-allocate temporarily since</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we don&#39;t know how big the record is until we&#39;re finished writing it, so</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// even though we don&#39;t commit the extraneous data, we still can&#39;t guarantee</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we&#39;re at the end of the allocated data.</span></CodeLine>
